sen.j: 林 羅山（はやし らざん、天正11年（1583年） - 明暦3年1月23日 (旧暦)（1657年3月7日））は、江戸時代初期の朱子学派儒教、林家 (儒者)の祖。
sen.e: Razan HAYASHI (1583-1657) was the founder of the HAYASHI (or RIN) clan of Neo-Confucianism in the early years of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 4欄と5欄はつながった文章と判断しました。また辞典によると『林＝りん家』となっていたので併記しました。
sen.e: Razan HAYASHI (1583-1657) was the founder of the HAYASHI (or RIN) clan of Neo-Confucianism in the early years of the Edo period.
Razan HAYASHI (1583-1657) was the founder of the HAYASHI (or RIN) clan of Neo-Confucianism in the early years of the Edo period.

sen.j: 羅山は号で、諱は信勝（のぶかつ）。
sen.e: Razan was a pseudonym, and his real name was Nobukatsu.
Razan was a adopted name, his real name being Nobukatsu.
sen.cmt: I think pseudonym is used when there is an intention to hide the real name.
sen.e: Razan was an adopted name, his real name being Nobukatsu.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 字は子信。
sen.e: The azana (adult males nickname) was Shishin (子信).
sen.cmt: 子信の読み方がわかりません。
sen.e: His azana (courtesy name given to adult males) was Shishin (子信).
His azana (courtesy name given to adult males) was Shishin (子信).

sen.j: 通称又三郎。
sen.e: An ordinary name was Matasaburo.
He was popularly known as Matasaburo
He was popularly known as Matasaburo

sen.j: 出家した後の号、道春（どうしゅん）の名でも知られる。
sen.e: He was also recognized as Doshun, which was his Buddhist name.
When he became a Buddhist priest, he took the Buddhist name of Doshun.
When he became a Buddhist priest, he took the Buddhist name of Doshun.

sen.j: 天正11年(1583年)京都において産まれるが、ほどなく伯父へ養子に出される。
sen.e: He was adopted as his uncle's son soon after he was born in Kyoto in 1583.
He was adopted by his uncle soon after he was born in Kyoto in 1583.
He was adopted by his uncle soon after he was born in Kyoto in 1583.

sen.j: 小さい頃から秀才としてうたわれ、文禄4年(1595年)京都建仁寺で仏教を学ぶが、僧籍に入る（出家する）のは拒否し家に戻る。
sen.e: He was reputed to be a brilliant person from his childhood, and studied Buddhism at Kennin-ji Temple, Kyoto in 1595, however he returned to his house, refusing to enter into priesthood.
Reputed to be brilliant from an early age, he entered Kennin-ji Temple in Kyoto to study Buddhism in 1595, but refused to enter the priesthood and returned to his family.
sen.cmt: I think "family" is a better translation of "家" in this context.
sen.e: Reputed to be brilliant from an early age, he entered Kennin-ji Temple in Kyoto to study Buddhism in 1595, but refused to enter the priesthood and returned to his family.

sen.j: 独学を進めるうちに朱子学に熱中していき慶長9年(1604年)藤原惺窩（ふじわらせいか）に出会う。
sen.e: While studying by himself, he was absorbed in studying Neo-Confucianism, and had an encounter with Seika FUJIWARA in 1604.
In his private studies he became increasly absorbed in Neo-Confucianism, and met Seika FUJIWARA in 1604.
In his private studies he became increasingly absorbed in neo-Confucianism, and met Seika FUJIWARA in 1604.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 羅山にとって惺窩との出会いは、精神的、学問的に大きく影響を受けることになり、惺窩も羅山の英明さに驚き、翌年の1605年には徳川家康に会わせる。
sen.e: The encounter with Seika dramatically influenced Razan's mental and studies, meanwhile Seika was surprised at the brilliance of Razan and introduced Razan to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in 1605.

Razan was greatly influenced both emotionally and academically by his encounter with Seika, and Seika was surprised by Razan's brilliance and introduced Razan to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in the following year of 1605.

Razan was greatly influenced both spiritually and academically by his encounter with Seika, and Seika was surprised by Razan's brilliance and introduced Razan to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in the following year, 1605.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 惺窩の勧めもあり家康は、以後羅山を手元に置いていくことになる。
sen.e: On Seika's advice, Ieyasu kept Razan staying with him since then.
On Seika's advice, Ieyasu kept Razan close at hand from that point onwards.
On Seika's advice, Ieyasu kept Razan close at hand from that point onwards.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 羅山は家康に抜擢され、23歳の若さで家康のブレーンとなった。
sen.e: Singled out by Ieyasu, Razan became the brains behind Ieyasu at the young age of twenty-three.
Singled out by Ieyasu, Razan became the brains behind Ieyasu at the young age of twenty-three.
Singled out by Ieyasu, Razan became the brains behind Ieyasu at the young age of twenty-three.

sen.j: 1606年にはイエズス会の日本人修道士イルマン・ハビアンと「地球論争」を行っている。
sen.e: In 1606, he developed a discussion named "chikyu-ronso (controversy over the Earth)" with Irmao Fabian, a Japanese monk belonged to the Society of Jesus.
sen.cmt: イルマン・ハビアンはwebの記載を採用しましたが，Ｉｒｍａｏのaの上に～が必要です。
sen.e: In 1606, he was involved in "chikyu-ronso (controversy over the Earth)" with Irmao Fabian, a Japanese monk who belonged to the Society of Jesus.
sen.cmt: I think "involved" is better than "developed" here.
sen.e: In 1606, he was involved in "chikyu-ronso (controversy over the Earth)" with Irmao Fabian, a Japanese monk who belonged to the Society of Jesus.

sen.j: この時林羅山は地動説と地球が球体である事を断固として受け入れず、地球方形説と天動説を主張した。
sen.e: In the controversy, Razan HAYASHI emphatically denied the Copernican theory and an opinion that the earth is a sphere, and advocated the gradiate theory of earth and the Ptolemaic theory.
sen.cmt: 地球方形説はwebの記載を採用しましたが，スペルチェックにかかります。
sen.e: Razan HAYASHI refused to accept that the earth was round, advocating instead the theory that the earth was rectangular and sat at the center of the universe.
sen.cmt: Here, I think it is better not to name the theories in this way. Simple is OK.
sen.e: Razan HAYASHI refused to accept that the earth was round and revolves around the Sun, advocating instead the theory that the earth was rectangular and sat at the center of the universe.
sen.cmt: 以下の翻訳を追加しました。：「地球が球体である→and revolves around the Sun」

sen.j: この論争は林羅山がハビアンを論破する形で終わり、その後ハビアンは信仰に動揺を来たし、後の棄教につながっていく。
sen.e: This controversy came to an end in the form that Razan HAYASHI refuted Fabian, and afterward, Fabian wavered in his faith, which made him abandon the faith later.
The controversy ended with Razan HAYASHI winning the argument and Fabian would later question and subsequently abandon his faith.
The dispute ended with Razan HAYASHI winning the argument and Fabian would later question and subsequently abandon his faith.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 1607年には、江戸に赴き2代将軍徳川秀忠（家康の3男）に講書を行った。
sen.e: In 1607, Razan went to Edo and lectured to the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA (the third son of Ieyasu).
In 1607, Razan went to Edo and taught the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA (the third son of Ieyasu).
In 1607, Razan went to Edo and taught the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA (the third son of Ieyasu).

sen.j: 寛永元年(1624年)3代将軍・徳川家光（秀忠の長男）の侍講になり、以後幕府政治にも関わっていくことになる。
sen.e: In 1624, he became the jiko (teacher) of the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA (the eldest son of Hidetada), and after that, he took part in the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) government.
In 1624, he became jiko (teacher) of the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA (the eldest son of Hidetada), and thereafter joined the bakufu government (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
In 1624, he was appointed teacher of the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA (the eldest son of Hidetada), and subsequently joined the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) government.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。幕府の補足が分かりやすいよう順序を変えました。

sen.j: 寛永12年(1635年)武家諸法度の起草にあたり、翌1636年には伊勢神宮参拝典礼にもあたった。
sen.e: He took charge of a draft of Buke Shohatto (Laws for the Military Houses) in 1635, and managed the worship liturgy to Ise-jingu Shrine in 1636.
He was responsible for drafting Buke Shohatto (Laws for the Military Houses) in 1635, and managed the worship at Ise-jingu Shrine in 1636.
He was responsible for drafting Laws for the Military Houses in 1635, and managed the ceremony of visiting Ise-jingu Shrine in 1636.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。余分なスペースをのぞきました。

sen.j: なお寛永9年(1632年)上野忍が岡に、学問所を与えられ先聖殿と称した。
sen.e: Furthermore, in 1632, he was entrusted with an academic temple in Ueno-Shinobugaoka, and he named it Senseiden.
Furthermore, in 1632, he was entrusted with a school in Ueno-Shinobugaoka which he named Senseiden.
sen.cmt: I think "school" is better than "academic temple" here.
sen.e: Furthermore, in 1632, he was entrusted with a school in Ueno-Shinobugaoka which he named Senseiden.
sen.cmt: 「上野忍ヶ岡」を「Shinobugaoka at Ueno」としました。

sen.j: これが後の昌平坂学問所になる。
sen.e: This academic temple later became Shoheizaka Gakumonjo.
This school later became Shoheizaka Gakumonjo.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の学問所にあたり儒学を広げていく元となっていく。
sen.e: Shoheizaka Gakumonjo was an academic temple controlled by the Edo bakufu, and played a central role in propagating Confucianism.
Shoheizaka Gakumonjo was a school controlled by the Edo bakufu, and played a central role in propagating Confucianism.

sen.j: 羅山は、初期の幕府の土台作りに大きく関わり様々な制度、儀礼などのルールを定めていった。
sen.e: Participating in the task to lay the foundation of a newly-fledged bakufu, Razan made various rules, such as systems and courtesy.
Razan played an important role in the foundation of the newly-fledged bakufu, creating various systems and regulations governing matters such as courtesy.
sen.cmt: Promoted Razan to beginning of sentence.
sen.e: Razan played an important role in the foundation of the newly-fledged bakufu, creating various systems and regulations governing matters such as courtesy.

sen.j: 学問上では、儒学・神道以外の全てを排し、朱子学の発展、儒学の官学化に貢献した。
sen.e: In the field of study, he eliminated all learning except Confucianism and Shintoism, and contributed to the development of Neo-Confucianism and the promotion of Confucianism to the government-designated learning.

He removed all subjects other than Confucianism and Shintoism from the syllabus, and contributed to the development of Neo-Confucianism and the promotion of Confucianism as the learning of government.

He removed all subjects other than Confucianism and Shintoism from the syllabus, and contributed to the development of neo-Confucianism and the promotion of Confucianism as the learning of government.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 博識で学問だけでなく紀行書なども著すなど多彩な面がある。
sen.e: He had wide knowledge and had talents not only for learning but also for various aspects, for example, he wrote books about his travels and others.
A learned man, Razan was not only well-read, but had a number of other interests, including the penning of books on his travels and other subjects.
Razan was not only well-read, but had a number of other interests, including the penning of books on his travels and other subjects.

sen.j: なお、大学頭（だいがくのかみ）は、3代林鳳岡（羅山の孫）の時代からであり、以後林家は代々幕府の学問の責任者を担ってゆく（駿河文庫の管理を担う）。
sen.e: Meanwhile, HAYASHI (or RIN) clan had served as Daigaku no kami (Director of the Bureau of Education) since the days of the third descendant Hoko HAYASHI (grandchild of Razan), and after that, HAYASHI (or RIN) clan succeeded the post of the person responsible for learning in the bakufu from generation to generation (they were also entrusted with the management of the Suruga library).

The HAYASHI (or RIN) clan provided the Daigaku no kami (Director of the Bureau of Education) from the day of Hoko HAYASHI (grandchild of Razan and the third generation of the family), and would later provide officials for the inherited post responsible for educatoin in the bakufu (they were also entrusted with the management of the Suruga library).

The Hayashi (or RIN) family provided the Director of the Bureau of Education from the time of Hoko HAYASHI (grandchild of Razan and the third generation of the family), and would later provide officials for the inherited post responsible for education in the bakufu (they were also entrusted with the management of the Suruga library).

sen.j: 明暦2年(1656年)に妻を亡くした際には、その死を悼む詩を26首詠むなど愛妻家でもあった。
sen.e: Razan was such a devoted husband as to compose twenty-six poems to mourn over the death of his wife, when he lost her in 1656.

sen.e: Razan was a devoted husband, and, on the death of his wife in 1656, composed twenty-six poems in mourning.

sen.j: 翌年、明暦の大火によって邸宅と書庫を消失し、その4日後に死去した。
sen.e: In the next year (1657), he lost his residence and library in the Great Fire in Meireki, and died four days later.
The following year (1657), he lost his residence and library in the Great Fire of Meireki, and died four days later.

sen.j: 墓は東京都新宿区市谷山伏町にある。
sen.e: His grave is in Yamabushi town, Ichigaya, Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo Prefecture.
His grave is in Yamabushi town, Ichigaya, Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 林羅山は、朱子学者として、万物は「理」と「気」から成るとする理気二元論を説き、理法が諸現象を支配するのと同様に理性が情欲を支配することを理想とした。
sen.e: Razan HAYASHI, as a Neo-Confucian Scholar, expounded a dualism, in which he advocated that all things are composed of "ri (reason)" and "ki (body)", and idealized that reason controls lust as law controls phenomena.

As a Neo-Confucian Scholar, Razan HAYASHI expounded a dualism in which all things are composed of "ri (reason)" and "ki (body)" and described an ideal by which reason would govern lust in the same way that laws govern phenomena.

sen.j: また、上下定分の理を説いて士農工商の身分制度を正当化した。
sen.e: He also expounded the theory of fixed division between uppers and lowers, and justified the hierarchy of samurai, farmers, artisans, and merchants in Edo society.
He also expounded the theory of fixed division between uppers and lowers, and legitimized in Edo society a hierarchy with samurai at the top, followed by farmers, artisans, and merchants.
sen.cmt: I think "justified" is usually used about actions past. Here, "legitimized" seems to work better.
